results.title: Swedbank: not yet future-proof, but headed there
results.content:
Way to go.

Swedbank investors marked up its shares after its more-than 9 per cent increase in third-quarter net income from a year ago to SKr4.6bn beat expectations.

But they should really celebrate the Swedish lender's rigorous focus on returns, exemplified in CEO Michael Wolf's words:

The strong result gives us good opportunities, but we have to continue to work with internal efficiencies.

He's right. Sweden's central bank cut its main interest rate in July to just 0.25 per cent to ward off deflation risks. Swedbank can box around that to a point. But as low inflation heaps pressure on the Riksbank to cut rates further, the Swedish lender must keep cutting costs and boost productivity to buttress returns.

Excising between 600-800 jobs over two years – in effect, not replacing the 5.5 per cent of staff who leave or retire - is the way to go.

A further reason for discipline now is the uncertainty created by the upheaval in Ukraine, though Swedbank has not yet felt any knock-on effects in its Baltic business.

Even so, Swedbank's bad loan charge ticked up to SKr235m in the quarter. That's still a negligible proportion of its overall lending, but is one to watch.

As for revenue, net interest income was 3 per cent higher, the result of repricing mortgages and increasing lending volumes as the Swedish property market keeps rising. Fee income was resilient, increasing by 12 per cent.

Although expenses were 4 per cent higher overall, they climbed more slowly than expected. And luckily a 10 per cent increase in total income meant that it cost Swedbank just 41 oere to generate every krona of income, pulling down its cost-to-income ratio from 47 per cent in the second quarter.

Few investors will worry about Swedbank's common equity tier one ratio of 20.7 per cent. But as the Swedish property prices rise amid a housing shortage in urban areas and high household indebtedness a hot topic – a plump capital cushion is no bad thing. It's not as if Swedbank's loan-to-value ratio is remotely buccaneering.

Its shares trade at more than twice its tangible book value, so investors certainly pay up for the capital safety and resilience of Swedbank. But few lenders in the European landscape offer both of those plus an underlying return on equity of 16.6 per cent.

Not yet future-proof perhaps, but the next best thing.

results.title: US earnings season: sales surprise, outlook dims
results.content:
As third-quarter US earnings season shifts into a faster gear on Tuesday, a quick snapshot of what corporate America has delivered so far.

The proportion of S&P 500 companies eclipsing earnings estimates is running at 69 per cent which, according to analysts at Barclays, is in line with recent quarters.

The tally for those businesses topping for revenues is 64 per cent, shy of the second-quarter but better than the recent trend of 58 per cent.

It's worth pointing out that Wall Street analysts gradually trimmed revenue and profit expectations in the countdown to third-quarter earnings, giving companies an easier bar to hurdle.

What's more, analysts are already cutting estimate for the profits (measured by earnings per share) they expect S&P 500 companies to make in 2015 (see chart below) as global growth weakens.
results.abstract: As third-quarter US earnings season shifts into a faster gear on Tuesday, a quick snapshot of what corporate America has delivered so far.

results.title: Tesco trading resilient over past month - Kantar
results.content:
Tesco's trade improved over the past month, delivering a fillip to new chief executive Dave Lewis, ahead of delayed half-year results later this week.

According to Kantar Worldpanel, the consumer research group, Tesco's sales fell by 1.5 per cent in the four weeks to October 12, beaten only by Asda, reports Andrea Felsted, the FT's senior retail correspondent.

In contrast, sales at J Sainsbury, which said earlier this month that the grocery sector was suffering from a "perfect storm," fell by 4 per cent, while the decline at Wm Morrison, which has invested heavily in cutting prices, was 4.6 per cent.

Tesco's performance offers a glimmer of hope for Mr Lewis, who on Thursday is expected to report a near halving of first-half profit, after he revealed last month that an estimate announced just weeks earlier had been overstated by £250m.

The FT reported on Friday that Mr Lewis had told staff that the performance in food was improving.

He said in an internal memo that Tesco's "recent performance in Food has been one of our strongest for a very long time", adding:

Whilst one swallow does not make a summer, we can take some small comfort that our efforts are having an impact.

Industry insiders attributed the improvement to the promotions that Tesco has been carrying out to stimulate trade, together with lower petrol prices, which encourage customers to drive to out-of-town stores, also helped by the efforts that the supermarkets have made to pass on falling fuel prices.

Asda was the best performing of the big four in the four weeks, with sales falling by 1 per cent. The total grocery market was flat, with Aldi's sales still growing at 24.9 per cent and Lidl's increasing by 19 per cent.

Tesco's performance was poorer over the 12 weeks to October 12, when sales at Britain's biggest supermarket chain fell 3.6 per cent in the 12 weeks to October 12, the worst of the big four.

Sainsbury's sales fell 3.1 per cent over the 12-week period, while Morrison's sales slipped 1.8 per cent.
results.abstract: Tesco's trade improved over the past month, delivering a fillip to new chief executive Dave Lewis, ahead of delayed half-year results later this week.

results.title: Fast New York Open: US housing under scrutiny
results.content:
The defensive-minded utilities sector was the best performer even as the S&P 500 rose on Monday, and there are further signs on Tuesday that caution remains a watchword for investors after the swings of the last month.

While European equities are stronger across all of the continent's main bourses, US government bonds are also proving resilient.

The yield on the ten-year note remains below the 2.2 per cent, the top of the new trading range established after yields briefly surged lower to 1.86 per cent last week.

China's third-quarter growth of 7.3 per cent, released earlier on Tuesday, was better than expected but doesn't allay concern that the world's second-largest could slow more than Beijing wants as it tries to gently deflate a credit boom.

In the US, the economic calendar serves up existing home sales data for September.

Economists' forecast sales to have bounced 1 per cent to a 5.1m annualised rate after dropping in August. The figures are due at 10am local time.

While the housing market remains a key area of focus for the Federal Reserve, inflationary pressures - or the lack of them - is a bigger one. Inflation figures for September are due on Wednesday.

Otherwise, third-quarter earnings finds a fresh gear with Coca-Cola, McDonald's, Verizon and Yahoo all reporting.

S&P 500 futures suggest the US stock market will open modestly higher.
results.abstract: The defensive-minded utilities sector was the best performer even as the S&P 500 rose on Monday, and there are further signs on Tuesday that caution remains a watchword for investors after the swings of the last month.

results.title: Euro slips, stocks rise on ECB bond buying report
results.content:
European stock markets are higher and the euro has tumbled on reports that the European Central Bank is looking at buying corporate bonds, which would mark a significant expansion in its move to ease monetary policy.

Reuters has reported that the ECB could decide to start buying corporate debt as early as December, with purchases starting early next year, citing people familiar with the matter.

The ECB yesterday started buying covered bonds – ultra safe bank debt backed by underlying assets like mortgages – but expanding its asset purchase programme to encompass riskier corporate bonds would be a big move by the central bank.

The report helped reverse the euro's earlier gain to as high as $1.284 this morning to $1.2777 at pixel time, down 0.2 per cent today, and helped the Eurofirst 300 stock market index to a 0.9 per cent climb so far on Tuesday. It has also helped pare or reverse today's rise in eurozone periphery bond yields.

One source told Reuters:

In the view of many Governing Council members, the economic picture has recently taken a turn for the worse.
results.abstract: European stock markets are higher and the euro has tumbled on reports that the European Central Bank is looking at buying corporate bonds, which would mark a significant expansion in its move to ease monetary policy.

results.title: Sands China defies gambling slowdown
results.content:
Sands China managed to grow profits in the third quarter despite a broader slowdown in the gambling enclave of Macau.

The casino operator said profit grew 3.9 per cent to $643.1m in the three months to end- September.

Low single-digit growth is less than exciting, but amid the broader climate it's pretty positive. Sands' shares have fallen 30 per cent this year as traffic to the island has declined.

Overall, Macau's Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau said total revenue in the former Portuguese colony fell 11.7 per cent from a year ago in September to 25.6bn Macau patacas.

That was the sharpest revenue decline since June 2009 and the fourth straight drop overall, as high-rolling clients turned cautious amid an anti-luxury crackdown by Chinese president Xi Jinping.

Sands certainly hasn't been immune. Total net revenues fell 0.2 per cent $2.32bn from a year ago and, as trailed last week by its parent, Las Vegas Sands, earnings fell at three of its four big Macau gaming sites:

  • Venetian Macao: -1.2%
  • Sands Cotai Central: +19%
  • Plaza Macao: -11.7%
  • Sands Macao: -2.2%

Earnings at Sands Cotai Central climbed on a 39 per cent jump in "robust electronic table games," which reached a property record $2.03bn.

Barclays last week reiterated its overweight rating on the stock, saying there was upside as the parent company lifted its 2015 dividend by 30 per cent and authorised an additional US$2bn buyback.
results.abstract: Sands China managed to grow profits in the third quarter despite a broader slowdown in the gambling enclave of Macau.

results.title: UK public sector borrowing climbs again
results.content:
The UK's budget deficit widened again to £11.8bn in September, higher than expected and in spite of the buoyant economic recovery.

The latest public sector deficit and borrowing figures from the Office for National Statistics – excluding the public sector banks – underscore the difficulty the UK government is facing in taming the country's mounting debt burden.

The median estimate of economists polled by Bloomberg was for the public sector's net borrowing to fall to £10.1bn last month. Adding to the poor picture, last month's deficit was revised up slightly from £11.6bn to £11.7bn.

The Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government has made reducing the UK's budget deficit a flagship policy, but barring a marked turnaround in the last few months of the year public sector borrowing will be significantly higher this year than last.

Samuel Tombs of Capital Economics wrote:

The continued run of poor UK public borrowing figures looks set to severely hamper the Chancellor's ability to announce giveaways to address his party's deficit in the national opinion polls before next year's general election.

... Borrowing would have to be a whopping 37% lower than last year in the remaining six months of the fiscal year for the annual total to match the OBR's forecast. Accordingly, the Chancellor will be forced to acknowledge in December's Autumn Statement that the fiscal consolidation is not going to plan, limiting his scope to announce pre-election sweeteners.
results.abstract: The UK's budget deficit widened again to £11.8bn in September, higher than expected and in spite of the buoyant economic recovery.

results.title: Oscar Pistorius handed five year jail sentence
results.content:
Oscar Pistorius, the South African Olympic and Paralymic star, has been sentenced to five years in jail for the culpable homicide, or manslaughter, of his model girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp.

The sentencing by Judge Thokozile Masipa is the final chapter of a trial that has at times been controversial and which throughout has been packed with incredible drama and emotion, captivating a global television audience, reports Andrew England in Johannesburg.

Mr Pistorius was formally found guilty of "culpable homicide" and one count of contravening weapons act by firing a 9mm pistol in a busy restaurant.

For a separate conviction of contravening a firearms act, Pistorius was sentenced to three years, which was suspended for five years. The two sentences would run concurrently.

In making her ruling, Judge Masipa said she wanted a sentence that was fair and just to both society and the accused.

She said a non-custodial sentence "would send the wrong message to the community," while adding that "on the other hand a long sentence would not be appropriate as it would lack the element of mercy".

It is a trial that has borne witness to the spectacular fall from grace of one of the world's most recognisable athletes: a double-amputee who earned iconic status in South Africa and beyond after competing against able-bodied track stars in the 2012 London Olympics.

During the sentencing process last week, Mr Pistorius's defence described the 27-year-old as a broken man.

"He was an icon for what he has achieved. He's lost everything. He lost all his sponsors. He lost all his money," Barry Roux, defence lawyer, told the court in Pretoria, South Africa's capital. "He has nothing. There is nothing left of this man."

Mr Roux had argued that Mr Pistorius – dubbed the "blade-runner" because of the distinct carbon fibre blades he runs on - should be given community service. He said he had been punished enough and shown remorse for shooting to death Reeva Steenkamp, his girlfriend, during the early hours of Valentine's Day last year.

But the prosecution countered that Mr Pistorius should be jailed for a minimum of 10 years. In South Africa, the sentence for culpable homicide can range from a fine to lengthy imprisonment.

"We shouldn't fail the parents. We shouldn't fail society," Gerrie Nel, the leader prosecutor, said ahead of the sentencing. "Society may lose its trust in the court."

During the arguments, South Africa's overcrowded prison system was effectively put on trial, with the defence claiming that Mr Pistorius's disabilities would make him particularly vulnerable in prison.

Mr Pistorius was born without fibula bones in his legs but overcame his disabilities to become a global star. Most notably, he reached the semi-finals of the 400 metres at the London Olympics after fighting for his right to run against able-bodied athletes, while also helping bring unprecedented attention to the Paralympics.

But less than a year later, he made international headlines for all the wrong reasons when police where called to his home in a wealthy suburb of Pretoria in the early hours of February 14 2013.

They discovered that Mr Pistorius had killed Steenkamp, a 29-year-old model and law graduate, by firing the 9mm pistol he kept by his bed four times through the locked toilet door of an en-suite bedroom.

In his defence, Mr Pistorius has insisted that the killing was a terrible accident after he mistakenly thought an intruder had entered his house through a bathroom window.

In her judgement last month, Judge Masipa criticised Mr Pistorius as a poor and evasive witness. But in finding him not guilty of murder, she decided that he genuinely believed that someone had broken into the house at the time of the shooting and posed a risk to him and Steenkamp.

The judgement sparked a swirl of controversy in South Africa, with some legal experts and commentators questioning her decision to acquit Mr Pistorius of murder.

There has also been speculation that either the defence or prosecution could appeal, depending on the sentencing.
results.abstract: Oscar Pistorius, the South African Olympic and Paralymic star, has been sentenced to five years in jail for the culpable homicide, or manslaughter, of his model girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp.

results.title: Markets open higher, ignoring Asian weakness
results.content:
European equities are now climbing after a weak start, with investors shrugging off a poor session in Asia propelled by China's GDP slowing to a half-decade low.

The Euro Stoxx benchmark is up 0.5 per cent, or 15 points, while in New York futures point to a slight rise for the S&P 500.

The upward moves follow a sell-off in Asia after China posted a 7.3 per cent growth rate in the third quarter. The Shanghai Composite dropped 0.7 per cent after the report, while Korea's Kospi fell 0.8 per cent. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 average fell 2 per cent, unravelling half of Monday's gain.

Gavekal Dragonomics said the slowdown in China was widely expected, as Beijing isn't willing to increase its debt burden with fiscal stimulus.

Following the rapid build-up of leverage over recent years, China's balance sheet looks very stretched. Mending it will take time.

After the sharp sell-off in recent weeks China's slowdown looks priced into European markets, allowing the main indices to move higher.

  • The FTSE 100 in London is up 0.25 per cent or 16 points at at 6,282.

  • The Xetra Dax in Frankfurt is up 0.6 per cent or 49 points at 8,767.

  • The CAC 40 in Paris is up 0.6 per cent or 25 points at 4,017.

Among the big movers, online fashion retailer Asos is leading the market, gaining nearly 17 per cent after it reported full year results that were less bad than anticipated.

InterContinental Hotels' stock fell 1.5 per cent despite reporting higher than anticipated revenue thanks to solid demand in the US.

Shares of Arm Holdings first rose 3.3 per cent after the UK chip designer reported that royalty momentum picked up last quarter, but then they reversed direction and entered negative territory.

Shares of Total fell half a per cent after the French oil and gas giant confirmed its CEO, Christophe de Margerie, died after his private plane crashed.
results.abstract: European equities are now climbing after a weak start, with investors shrugging off a poor session in Asia propelled by China's GDP slowing to a half-decade low.

results.title: BCA shelves its IPO after stock market wobble
results.content:
Another initial public offering bites the dust.

Used car auctioneer BCA Marketplace has pulled its £200m IPO after a bruising month for global stock markets that has led to a rash of cancelled listings and forced others to markedly mute their pricing expectations.

BCA is owned by private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and says it is Europe's biggest used car marketplace, with over 900,000 vehicles sold last year. The company hoped to list about 25 per cent of its shares by November, using the proceeds to pay down debts.

But the recent market turmoil has stymied its plans, leading the company's board and private equity owner to shelve its IPO plans for now. This follows Virgin Money and Aldermore announcing last week they would delay their listings, and Jimmy Choo pricing right at the bottom of its price range.

In a statement to the London Stock Exchange BCA said:

The Board and Shareholders were very encouraged by the broad engagement and interest in BCA shown by investors and remain excited about supporting the next phase of the Group's growth.

BCA has an excellent track record as Europe's leading used vehicle marketplace with strong revenues and earnings growth on the back of momentum across its physical and digital platforms.
results.abstract: Another initial public offering bites the dust.
